column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country- subject to categorisation.
Document checklist
Travelers from red countries can enter Malta without further restrictions if they provide all the following documents:
1. Submit their passenger locator form and provide the QR code at check in and on arrival in Malta in digital format. 2. One of the following certificates:
• Proof of full vaccination.
• Proof of recovery from COVID-19. Validity: 180 days (6 months)
• Negative result to a pre-departure test. *Holders of a valid residency card who were abroad between 17 January are exempt from quarantine if they provide a negative molecular (PCR) valid test result, valid 72 hours, and apply for and take the booster dose within 5 days after arrival. They provide proof that they were already abroad on 17 January 2022. This exemption does not apply to people returning from dark red zones.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- subject to categorisation.
Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Malta's national classification.
Travelers must quarantine for 14 days in the following cases:
Authorized travelers from dark red countries / zones. Quarantine is reduced to 7 days if they who hold valid proof of full vaccination.
All authorized travelers from red countries / zones who do not hold the documents required.
Travelers must quarantine at own cost (EUR 100 per night including breakfast only) in an accommodation provided by the Health Authorities. Molecular tests administered by public health authorities are subject to a EUR120 fee.
column4:
The Vaccine Certificate is only valid if:
Proof of full vaccination.
Validity: between 14 days and 9 months after the primary vaccination series was completed, or after the booster dose. For people younger than 18, the validity of vaccination certificates with a full primary series is valid indefinitely.
column5:
Latest news: Authorities will ease COVID-19 entry rules for recovered, recently tested travelers from 11 April (Schengen Visa Info, 05.04.2022)

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU: [as below]

*Transit:

Transit is only permitted through Malta International Airport provided the passenger does not exit the airport building.

Transit from the seaport to the airport and vice versa is not permitted.

A designated area has been identified to allow for transit of passengers



*From Third Countries:

Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Malta's national classification. Travel is allowed for people who have spent the previous 14 days in red countries.

From dark red countries, a travel ban applies. Entry from these areas is only permitted for essential travel in exceptional cases and only with priori authorisation. Applications must be submitted through this Travel authorisation form. Travelers from dark red countries cannot transit through Malta.

 

Document checklist

Travelers from red countries can enter Malta without further restrictions if they provide all the following documents:

  1. Submit their passenger locator form and provide the QR code at check in and on arrival in Malta in digital format.

  2. One of the following certificates:
  • Proof of full vaccination.
    Validity: between 14 and 270 days (9 months) after the primary vaccination series was completed, or after the booster dose. For people younger than 18, the validity of vaccination certificates with a full primary series is valid indefinitely.

    Accepted vaccines - See the accepted vaccines on traveltomalta.gov.mt:
    - Vaccines approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA): Comirnaty (Pfizer), Janssen, Spikevax (Moderna), Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca), Nuvaxovid (NVX - CoV2373).
    - Primary full series with vaccines accepted by the World Health Organization (WHO), provided that a booster dose with a vaccine approved by EMA was administered. Note: holders of vaccination certificates with WHO vaccines not yet approved by EMA must provide a negative result to a pre-departure molecular test, valid 72 hours.
    - Primary full series with vaccines approved by WHO and booster dose with a vaccine by EMA.

    The following documents are accepted as proof of vaccination:
    An 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC) or equivalent documents, meeting the requirements listed above.
    Other certificates meeting the same validity requirements as the EUDCC and with vaccines listed on traveltomalta.gov.mt.

  • Proof of recovery from COVID-19.
    Validity:
    - 180 days (6 months), if it is provided as an EUDCC or equivalent documents.
    - Other certificates of recovery from COVID-19 are also accepted, but they are valid between 14 and 180 days and they must be supplemented by a negative result to a pre-departure molecular (PCR) test, valid 72 hours.
  • Negative result to a pre-departure test.
    Accepted documents:
    - An EUDCC, an equivalent document, or a similar certificate issued in English (or translated into English) by an accredited lab with a negative molecular (PCR) test result, valid 72 hours.
    - An EUDCC or an equivalent document with a negative result to a rapid antigen test included in the European Commission's list of rapid antigen tests, valid 24 hours. Other certificates with rapid antigen tests are not accepted.

 

Travelers must quarantine for 14 days in the following cases:

  • Authorized travelers from dark red countries / zones. Quarantine is reduced to 7 days if they who hold valid proof of full vaccination. Further details are available in the Standards for quarantine.
  • All authorized travelers from red countries / zones who do not hold the documents required.

 

Children younger than 6 are exempt from pre-departure testing requirements.

 

Details on rules and further exemptions from quarantine are available on traveltomalta.gov.mt.

 

Learn more:
Validity of vaccination, recovery and test certificates
Standards for quarantine

You can find the latest information on air travel regulations for this country on the IATA website.

You can also find information about your passenger rights on our portal for citizens.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Malta: Passengers on public transport, including the Gozo ferry and clients of commercial entities must wear face masks.
Public spaces and services: It is mandatory to wear a face mask in all indoor public spaces (children under 3 are exempt). Masks are not required in outdoor public spaces.
Presentation of a valid vaccination certificate, for those aged 12 and over, is mandatory for entry into bars, nighclubs, casinos, gaming parlours and bingo halls.
There is a limit of 8 people per table in hospitality establishments. Masks are to be worn inside, unless seated and eating or drinking. If you live in England, Scotland, Northern Ireland or Wales, Malta will accept the COVID vaccine certification (both the digital and letter versions) as proof of your vaccination status. Digital certificates must include a verifiable 2D barcode (QR code). Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
If you are resident in Malta and have a Maltese-issued vaccination certificate, the validity of your certificate is as follows:
• The certificate is valid for 3 months from the date of the second dose (or the first dose for Jannsen / Johnson and Johnson vaccine)
• The certificate is valid for 9 months from the date of the third dose (booster vaccination)
For vaccination certificates issued outside of Malta, the validity of that certificate will apply.
Full details of exemptions from mask wearing are available online. Medical exemptions must be certified by a medical professional.
Full information is available on the Maltese government coronavirus advice page *If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
